Yes — everything is committed (both repos), but **nothing could be pushed yet** because **neither repo has a remote configured** (`git push` fails with “No configured push destination”).

- **Root repo** (C:\Users\Dell\Downloads\Nouveau dossier (3)): commit **c89ddf2** on `master` (working tree clean)
- **Nested repo** (C:\Users\Dell\Downloads\Nouveau dossier (3)\Nouveau dossier (3)): commit **f3e8376** on `master` (working tree clean)

To push them, I need the remote URL(s) (GitHub/GitLab HTTPS/SSH). Once you paste them, I’ll set `origin` and push.

If you already know the URLs, these are the exact commands I’ll run:

```bash
# root repo
git remote add origin <ROOT_REMOTE_URL>
git push -u origin master

# nested repo
git remote add origin <NESTED_REMOTE_URL>
git push -u origin master
```

 `<ROOT_REMOTE_URL>` and `<NESTED_REMOTE_URL>` (or “only push root” / “only push nested”).
